title: I'm a little sad that Beatrice/Demon of Secrets and characters like it aren't explored more fully

replies.body: I've seen a writer confirm that their stories genuinely have a word limit, so take that for what you will.

This is correct. Short bios are now ~80 words, max 100. Full bios shouldn't be more than 600 words without good reason. Color stories are ~1,000 words, max 1,250. (All of this is because of writer and editor bandwidth. If you feel you'd like more words, please let us know!)

Regular short stories, like 'The Principles of Strength', have no limit. We will tell whatever length of story is appropriate for the plot. :-)

IMHO, good fiction does not data-dump for brevity of worldbuilding. If we've deliberately avoided talking about something that seems like it should be a huge part of the story... then I'd urge you to consider why that might be... ;-)

Then make one of your little hints pay off. Please.
True there's been a lot of setup and never any payoff

Yes, I'd like more words. OR less content crammed in Champions' Bio with more side stories to compensate. But I totally agree with OP here, the passage about the Demon in Swain's Bio absolutely needs more details. 

I'll even go further and say the same about LeBlanc's Bio and the passage about Mordekaiser and the Darkin Wars. If you have a word limit, you can cut ideas and say less stuff, but you should not cut the quality to say as much stuff in less words, IMHO. That just leaves a bad feeling of rushed writing to me. Ironical, I don't doubt, because I'm sure the first version is much longer and the short one is the result of a lot of work and countless edits, but still... That's how I feel reading the stories.

Honestly it often feels like you haven't figured it out yet or don't want to write yourselves into a corner early on. When you brush over information we're looking for, like how swain found and took on a demon that's core to his character, it just seems like you didn't get that far at figuring it out

> [{quoted}](name=Scathlocke,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=g3fhfMJL,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2018-02-06T06:21:34.026+0000)

> IMHO, good fiction does not data-dump for brevity of worldbuilding. If we've deliberately avoided talking about something that seems like it should be a huge part of the story... then I'd urge you to consider why that might be... ;-)

See, the problem with that is that we, as players, have no idea if you're not mentioning something because it's been entirely cut, or because it's being saved for a future update. Beatrice was a huge part of Swain's lore and character before, and all we've gotten about her is that you didn't feel that the new Swain would work as a 'companion character', whatever that might mean. We've no real word on whether she's at the least part of his lore, after she's been cut from his gameplay. 
Saying 'maybe we're just saving it for future updates! OOOH MYSTERY!' in response to people asking for clarification is honestly more of an annoyance than anything. If you're going to do something with it, or anything, please just state it outright instead. Sometimes, a vague allusion is worse than no answer at all. 
I know your reply might've been mostly aimed at Swain's new demon pal and not Beatrice, assuming the two aren't now the same (another thing we've had no clarification on), but the original post mentioned her, so it still seemed relevant. 

Point being, when you've just done a MAJOR rework to a character that at least some people cared a lot about, keeping very little of his previous appearance and lore, answering honest questions with "Wait and see" just doesn't work when people are just trying to figure out if there's -anything- left of what they considered character defining aspects.

I just want to say that is kinda ironic that the "Short" stories have no limit of words, but the rest of the lore/bios do have a limit.

(Nothing wrong with that, but it made me laugh a bit)

I think the point was to leave a hanging plot thread to pick up later in the year/future updates.

I would've liked more details on the extent of his power, as well as how he pulled it off. But perhaps vague mystery is the best route for now.

"Terror coming... vagueness coming!"

Yeah, I'm not saying that it will never ever be explained, and there's nothing wrong with a cliffhanger that can be expanded later. I just think the frustration comes from the fact that we basically get more information about the Demon from Swain's in-game kit than from the actual lore. Especially since they still have so many characters that need to be canonized, it'll probably be a very long time before Swain and other characters with integral side characters get more lore, and that kinda blows when we don't know much about them in the first place.

Here's hoping to that future update sooner rather than later.

They're still playing the long game here. I have no doubt that we'll one day get some details on that (provided League of Legends lasts long enough).

The lore team is still playing catch-up on all of the characters and everything from the retcon; once they're reasonably caught up, we can really get the ball rolling on some innovative story-telling, I think. But it's going to take some more time; that much is clear.

Yeah, I definitely think old characters should get updated lore before we get additional stories, I'm just a little sad they couldn't throw in a couple sentences to clear a few things up. I'm a huge fan of the Souls games so I'm used to making lore conclusions with basically no promise of future explanation so vagueness definitely isn't always a bad thing.

Ever since I read Swain's new lore I kept on thinking that the way he conquered the demon is a _secret_ , which is a pun, because the demon is a demon of _secrets_    
_wink wink_

My theory is that whoever is in charge of proof reading and editing is just lazy so they set a limit on how much the writers can write lol.

{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}
That's what Riot does. They leave bread crumbs and I've far been annoyed by it.

"It's not even horrible storytelling, it's just so vague and leaves so much to be desired."

How do you say it's not horrible and then say what makes it horrible? It is horrible. They tried to tell too much for the amount of space they allotted.

''It's not even horrible storytelling, it's just so vague and leaves so much to be desired.''
This right here is why I haven't been fond of their bio rewrites, they strip the personality of the character out of their background without giving a reason or replacement for the narrative; each time leaving behind some unfulfilling and uninteresting filler, stupefying the whole point of their background in the first place. It's not that vagueness can't be a good tool for storytelling, but it'll drown out any plot if there's too much of it; compare it to fiddlesticks for example, some unexpectedly possessed scarecrow that's supposed to be a sign of the end times, leaves a lot to speculation without making it feel pointless.
